Perhaps you didn't read what Ms. Greenhouse wrote. She addresses "valid science" quite directly. It doesn't become invalid because you don't like it.

from her article above:
... scientific articles on the mechanism of levonorgestrel, the synthetic hormone that is the drug’s active ingredient, demonstrates that Plan B is not about abortion. It immobilizes sperm and prevents or delays ovulation. In other words, when taken shortly after unprotected intercourse, Plan B works as birth control, by preventing rather than terminating a pregnancy. (The F.D.A.-approved label for Plan B raises the possibility that the drug might also work by preventing a fertilized egg from implanting in the uterus to begin a pregnancy, but the National Institutes of Health has removed language raising this prospect from its Web site, and the N.I.H. biochemist in charge of research on contraception has said the language should also be taken off the label. Judge Korman called the prospect that Plan B might permit fertilization but prevent implantation “scientifically unsupported speculation.”)

As for your definition of a pregnancy, you claim implantation is a legal definition, not a scientific one. As someone who works in healthcare, that's certainly not the medical consensus. You can define it however you want, but you can't base legal and policy decisions on your personal definition.

And what is the constitutional protection that is being violated by allowing direct access to safe contraception?

This country is not governed by lawyers. It's governed by Laws. Lawyers represent real people (and corporations) and advocate for their rights and privileges under the laws which govern our society.

I think it is outrageous or just plain idiotic to assert as you have that a society "run by lawyers . . . just as bad as one run by the clergy"

The difference between lawyers and the clergy is that lawyers appeal to the Law as authority and Judges apply Law to the facts before them. Clergy apply "revealed" religious doctrine.

Why don't you read the Judge's decision and explain why the Judge got it wrong instead of complain that Judges are making the Law. Judges do make the Law to some extent because it is their role in our Republican government to adjudicate the rights - both constitutional and statutory - that we have as citizens. In this case, the FDA violated that right by acting in an arbitrary and capricious manner, in violation of the rights afforded by Congress under the Administrative Procedure Act.

As a voter, feel free to lobby your Congressional representatives to repeal the Administrative Procedure Act. If you'd like to have clerics running the FDA, you can lobby your fellow citizens to repeal the First Amendment and other Constitutional rights. Thankfully, I don't think many Americans would support your crusade, but no one is stopping you.

Will we ever learn? Time for a system-wide private bankruptcy proceeding. The Fed could do it next week.

Neither Friedman nor Phelps was the first to argue that the Phillips curve was not a stable long term tradeoff.

Priority belongs to Samuelson and Solow in their 1960 AER paper introducing the Phillips curve to the AEA. They did show a figureand use the word "menu" in the legend. The first and second full paragraph after the figure read and I quote ( possible typos mine)

"Aside from the usual warning that these are simply our best guesses, we must give another caution. All of our discussion has been phrased in short-run terms, dealing with what might happen in the next few years. It would be wrong, though, to think that our Figure 2 menu that related obtainable price and unemployment behavior will maintain its same shape over in the longer run. What we do in a policy way during the next few years might cause it to shift in a definite way.

Thus it is possible that after they had produced a low-pressure economy, the believers in demand-pull might be disappointed in the short run; i.e., prices might continue to rise even though unemployment was considerable. Nevertheless, it might e that the low-pressure demand would so act upon wage and other expectations as to shift the curve downward in the longer run - so that over a decade, the economy might enjoy higher employment with price stability than our present-day estimate would indicate."

Congress created the FDA and tasked it with the job of making administrative rules and regulations in the public interest. It wouldn't be very efficient for Congress to have to vote every time a new drug came to market. So Congress has delegated that authority to the FDA and the FDA is not supposed to base its decisions on purely political considerations.

If you think that as a matter of public policy, this drug should not be available to children, then write your Congressional representatives. Congress can pass a law that overrules the FDA.

What Congress should not be allowed to do is delegate to the FDA and then have the FDA base its decisions on purely political considerations. That's fine for Congress to do because we can hold politicians accountable in an election if we don't like what they do. However, we can't vote civil servants or the head of the FDA out of office.

Therefore, the FDA should base its decisions solely on scientific, evidence based medical grounds. If it's not more dangerous than other over the counter medicines available to minors, then the FDA has no basis to withhold approval because of political or religious objections.

Anyone upset with the policy outcome should be mad at Congress for delegating this to the FDA. It's absolutely inappropriate to criticize the judiciary for following the law and applying it without regard to political correctness.
